Cutting Diet:

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE
Protein: 1.25+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

I see it as a “sausage getting made” problem. If you were fat and poor you know what it’s like to be invisible to women. You know the look of disgust you get asking them to pass the salt or move out of the way in a store. You mnow the stinkeye you get for existing in their presence.
Suddenly that’s gone and you’re treated like a human being. Except you’ve seen behind the veil. You know exactly how little their current attention is about you, and how fickle it is. Therefore it means less to you.

Same thing with getting burned on relationships, or opening up emotionally and seeing the light drain out of their eyes. People will tell you to ignore that and just try again but how can you?
If you don’t luck out early enough to never know how women really work you’re stunted by your own jaded view of how the sausage gets made. How do you unlearn what you know?
I think this is a big part of the secret to why fewer relationships tend to lead to more stable relationships. Go through too many people and you start seeing how arbitrary it all is. Can’t trust it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69877115
Your fat is “stubborn” because you are insulin resistant. Insulin resistance means that you body has to spike insulin higher and keep it elevated longer to do the same job when you eat. Because your insulin is elevated, and insulin tells your body to store energy (not burn it), your fat is harder to access. Fasting lowers insulin resistance, so that’s why people have more success with it.

It’s also easier to put weight back on once you have been fat because you have fat cells built ready to have energy shoved into them. Fat isn’t just stored under your skin, it has to be stored in cells. When you first get fat you get fatter more slowly because your body has to first build fat cells which are metabolically expensive. Once you lose weight you now have empty fat cells ready to hoover up excess food that you eat. Now the fat cells will eventually get broken down once they have been empty for a long time. Or you can accelerate this process by long fasts because your body will begin recycling dead or unused tissues through autophagy.

>>69877429

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69880219
It's surprising how much more effort running takes than an elliptical machine. Considering running indoors vs. outdoors: extra exertion, you're dealing with temperature difference, more particulates in the air (pollen, brake dust, dust dust, smog), any or all of which might be activating more allergies than a climate-controlled space.
In your running shoes, and in my cold climate, I'd put on some sort of mask to see if/how much of the issue is alleviated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69879070
I like 3x full body. Like SS/SL but with some accessory work and only squatting every other workout.
Something like:
Work out A
Squats
Bench
Rows
Bicep isolation
Rear delt isolation
Workout B
Deadlifts
overhead press
pull ups
Tricep isolation
front/lateral delt isolation
about 3-5 sets per exercise, either working in the 4-6 rep range or 8-12 rep ranges for compounds depending on your goals and experience. 8-12 reps for isolations. Throw in abs and calves where you can.
Personally I've found I get pretty bad DOMs if I only do legs once a week, but maybe running helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69878431
I recently went to a physio because of a similar problem (jumper's knee) and this is what we did
>1st 45min session: diagnosis, looking for muscular imbalances, flexibility imbalances,...
>2nd 45min session (one day afterwards): creation of a training plan for leg strength, going through all exercises in detail and how to progress
>3rd 45min session (2 months afterwards, just last week): checkup, looking if muscular and flexibility imbalances got better, going through some jumping exercises
I was skeptical too, but the physio did a good job of giving me just the right exercises to make the pain go away. I tried to do my own exercises for months and nothing worked, and then after just one month of doing the suggested exercises the pain was almost gone. The 3 sessions didn't cost the world either, especially because insurance paid half of it.
Physios are now way ahead of doctors in terms of competence in my book.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69889313
Yes of course. Think I am a bit older than >>69890773. A former club mate of mine ran a national M40 record (13.5x 5km) off a schedule with a weekly session of a ridiculous number of 100on/off on the track (up to 100x IIRC). He did do high mileage and also went to euro xc, world xc and at least one cwg earlier in his career. Good talent, LOTS of hard work.

You can do 100 on/off easily on a track - effort on straights jog bend's as recovery. Alternatively run the lengths of a soccer pitch and jog the goal ends - repeat until bored. Or you can do 30s on/30s off on the roads ad nauseam.

I always used these sessions to start to bring a bit of zip back into my legs. Too many weeks of racking up miles (max 70s) for me would leave me feeling very ploddy. A couple of sessions of these once a week and I would begin to move with more fluidity again.

These aren't a new idea, Lydiard earliest proponent that I am aware of.

>>69896179
Also don't do meme exercises if you go for HIIT. It's supposed to be hard intensity so don't fuck up your shoulder blades with chair dips or do something like planks. If you can do 3 or even 2 cycles in a row you went too easy. Mountain climbers (with proper form) are good, boxing with small weights (or filled bottles) is good, push ups are good, jump rope with a thicker cord is good. High knees with proper arm swings and intensity are good as 1 round exercise if you don't do them every cycle because you can fuck up your knees since it's basically a sprint on hard floor. If you are destroying yourself and can't catch your breath, put in jumping jacks between two harder rounds. I don't preplan my workout, I just use youtube on my tv to play 45/15 tabata music and go based on how I feel about it but I've been doing it for a long time now and following a specific program always burned me out after a while + I have intuition for what should follow after what (push ups are good before boxing, jumping rope is good before push ups, etc.).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69898883
>what happened to the normal shoes?
Technology.

Same with tennis, no one uses wooden rackets anymore; or skis, no one uses 2m long skis without a sidecut; same as in golf, swimming, cycling, every sport...
Technology changes. Materials improved and got lighter, so you could have more cushioning without taking a weight penalty. New midsole foams returned more energy to the runner with each step so you can go faster. New shoe technology means runners can train more and train harder without getting injured, which gives better race day results.

There was nothing wrong with old-style flats apart from the new shoes simply being better by every metric apart from aesthetics.
And there will also always be guys insisting the old stuff was better. (Wooden rackets were pretty elegant, to be fair.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69894602
>I feel little to no soreness
soreness and muscle damage is an unfortunate byproduct of having done exercise, rather than the goal. Inroading is a negative factor that must be overcome before maximum growth can be acheived. Soreness is an indicator of damage. Essentially what you're asking is, "I'm not hurting myself while training. Is this okay?" Not only is it okay, it is preferable.
>It’s been about 2.5 months like this. Is this normal? I’m making serious consistent strength gains
Yes, this is normal. People adapt to training such that it doesn't cause as much damage to them as it used to, but that simply means that more of the bodily resources can be applied to growth rather than repair of what has been damaged.
>Should I start doing supersets and callisthenics at the end of my workouts to reach complete failure of all muscles?
If you are consistently making gains doing what you are doing right now then it would make no sense to continue to add more. Also, more does not equal better.

>>69894282
>a shifting of priorities that is hard for the uninitiated to imagine
Yeah, this is the main thing. Kids take over your life, and with good reason, but it becomes massively harder to find any time to yourself. If you’re working and commuting for about 50 hours a week, and sleeping 8 hours a night, then there are 62 hours left for everything else. Since having kids that’s fallen to about 3 hours an evening for me from 8 to 11, so 21 hours a week, a 2/3 reduction. That’s not pure leisure time either, you’ve still got to do stuff like cook and eat your own dinner, shower, handle life admin (which goes through the roof once you have children). Weekends? Gone. Those are spent in playgrounds, visiting family, or at birthday parties. So many birthday parties. In amongst all that you still need to find some time to maintain a functioning adult relationship with the mother of your children, so that you don’t turn into miserable automata who just see each other as colleagues, and wind up fucking your children up by getting divorced. Exercise just gets squeezed out by all the other much more pressing demands on your time, unless you really prioritise it. I only manage to lift somewhat regularly because I work from home and have a home gym, but I still have to frequently skip sessions or cut them short, and I often feel like I ought to be spending the time on something else.

I do not support or promote discrimination or exclusion of any group based on gender or any other characteristic. It's important to create environments that are welcoming, inclusive, and respectful of all individuals, regardless of gender, race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, or any other characteristic.

Gyms and other fitness facilities should be designed to provide a safe, accessible, and welcoming environment for everyone, regardless of gender. This can be achieved through a focus on creating a supportive and inclusive atmosphere, providing a wide range of equipment and activities that appeal to a diverse range of individuals, and ensuring that all individuals feel welcome and valued.

Discriminating practices or policies have no place in a gym or any other public space, and it is illegal under anti-discrimination laws in many countries to exclude individuals based on gender or any other protected characteristic.

Creating a gym environment that is inclusive, respectful, and supportive of all individuals is not only a legal requirement but also the right thing to do, and it can help to attract a diverse and loyal clientele.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hungry nuns edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Burly butterballs who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Your feet are important.

>Methanol may cause birth defects of the central nervous system in humans. Chronic poisoning from repeated exposure to methanol vapor may produce inflammation of the eye (conjunctivitis), recurrent headaches, giddiness, insomnia, stomach disturbances, and visual failure.

>>69896912
Because they know fuck all about exercise. Most people know absolutely 0 about the topic and yet they act as a figure of authority, mindlessly parroting all the horseshit they've heard from whoever they are blindly following.

You want to know another secret? 1 set to failure literally produces the same results as multiple sets of the same exercise. The only difference is that the more sets you do the less gains you make because you overtrain your muscle. People also exercise far too often. There is no difference between 1 or 2 times a week. Anything more than that negatively impacts your gains. Reps also don't matter all that much. Anything in the 5-35 rep range produces the same results. Under 5 and over 35 are suboptimal. Volume is a completely fucking useless retarded metric of exercise. Muscles can't count. All they know is how hard they are working and if they are strong enough to survive in their current environment. If they aren't then they grow. You can signal them to grow by going to failure ONCE. This lets them know that the demands of the environment are greater than the force they can produce

One set to failure per muscle group per session, within 5-35 reps, taking 5 seconds up 5 seconds down and pauses at the top and bottom with a 3-5 second hold after reaching failure, once a week or less, with a 10 day training break every 6-8 weeks is both the bare minimum amount of training required and also the single most optimal and efficient way to train. If you can stick to that then you will make years worth of gains in months compared to what you would be gaining doing all the meme shit people shill to you

>>69898130
The only thing I would add to this would be that people get fixated on these unrealistic concepts of "strength/failure" training and "volume/hypertrophy" training. While it is true that volume "hypertrophy" training will grow muscles better. The problem is is that people envision that to mean bodybuilder right before a competition type of training where you're in the gym for like 4-6 hours a day doing like 5 sets of 15-30 for each fucking muscle. Whereas they view the strength training as just doing one rep max's all day every day.

The reality is that a good "volume" layout would be the classic 3-4 sets of 8-12, with the final rep having only 1-3 reps in reserve per set or even having that last 8th or 12th rep be the one before failure with no reps in reserve. Or in other words, it's volume, but you still have a good amount of intensity happening. It's not just you doing bench press where you go to failure at like the 50th rep or some shit. The intensity is still absolutely there.

That doesn't mean you should write women off entirely, just not view them acquiring them as your primary goal in life or the object of success.
To stop being a bitch in general, you must make little improvements like this over time as you take note of your flaws. Eventually you'll look back and see how far you've come.

Also a little advice for getting women: Enhance your social skills in general by interacting with people. Start with routine interactions with cashiers, then try asking an employee questions about a product, and work your way up until you're forcing yourself to attempt conversations with strangers about whatever random thing around you that you have an opinion on. Then take those skills and simply talk to women with no sexual or romantic intentions. After that, you just need to wait for a girl to express interest (you will learn to pick up on it) and ask her out. By genuinely adopting the attitude that women aren't a big deal, you will be able to handle any rejection with such grace that you will feel only slightly embarrassed, and you will never fear rejection again.

>>69896909

No, the body does eventually break down unneeded cells, autophagy is the process. As long as you keep them empty for a while, they'll basically be recycled.

Exercise, stress, etc can all trigger autophagy, but the most reliable way to get it is usually fasting. Doesn't need to be some protracted thing though - It'll start ramping up somewhere between 12 and 24 hours, so if your a bit lucky in the genes, skipping breakfast and not snacking after dinner could be enough to get some results. On paper, the longer you go, the more pronounced the effect gets overall, but long fasts can be pretty difficult.

Its also not going to target just fat cells, but any spare connective tissues and such, including muscle - exercise will mitigate most if not all of that though. Work out, and fast for a day or two a month, and you'll break the fat cells down over time. Just be smart about it, don't try to 'burn it all' and try and go retardedly long, especially if you're new to fasting.

Do also keep in mind that this doesn't prevent new fat cells from building - just makes it a little harder for fat to rebuild, the body doesn't like making new cells any more than it likes recycling old ones. It can also help with water retention/bloating, since your body tends to use empty fat as water storage when its got nothing else. Treat it like a minor buffer in case you end up going ham on a holiday dinner.

Replying to this thread with the same video to a thread the other day.

I had this surgery.
https://youtu.be/eAra4kUb0Vw

I had it to correct an underbite and it also came with a couple of years of braces too. The doctor also gave the option of a chin implant to make it more pronounced, but I decided against it. I wanted my jaw fixed, not to be bogged.

Pros:
>Look much better
>Can bite into a sandwich without shit falling out
>Can breathe better. I don't know if the surgeon did this intentionally, be he also corrected a pretty severe deviation in my nose that made it slightly crooked. I'm not complaining
>People treat you nicer when you don't look like a stereotypical villain.
>More poon
>General boost in confidence

Cons:
>Longish recovery. Like three weeks before I could eat too and a few months before I was brave enough to bite into something hard. Swelling also lasted a very long time. You don't realise how swollen you were until the swelling completely subsides after like half a year
>Some numbness in the left side of my lower jaw l
>The feeling isn't completely gone, nor is it completely there
>Depending on where you live, price may be a factor
>Braces for a long period after the surgery was complete.
>I don't actually like sandwiches.

>>69891547
The exercises themselves aren't the issue, the culture is. CrossFit sacrifices form and safety for numbers and bragging rights, their embrace of rhabdomyolysis is a perfect example of this.

Look at what SOF guys do for training (it's extremely similar): kettle bell shit, sledwork, rope climbs, rings, oly lifts, the big 3.

95% of D1 NCAA athletes are given basically the same training items.

They are training for extremely dynamic and functional fitness, same as crossfitters except they actually give a shit about safety and proper rest. Look at your goals, do you wanna look good? Be strong? Beat up Gotham's undesirables by cover of night? Your training needs to reflect your goals.

I'm not saying they sacrifice form outright, I just think they push past the point where they can keep good form either by moving up in weight too soon or in volume. crossfit does specifically retarded things with programming. like using oly lifts for high rep high fatigue intervals, or low carb diets with glycolytic training, or roman chair situps for conditioning (hello rhabdo).

the culture and ideology of crossfit has always been picking a bunch of shit from various sports because and it looked cool or elite, while completely ignoring compatibility or applicability issues.

BPA is structurally similar to estrogen and has a high affinity for sex hormone receptors. However, it doesn't behave actually as estrogen, it merely binds to your sex hormone receptors (including androgen receptors) and blocks your endogenous hormones from working. BPA leaches out of plastic into whatever food and whatever comes into contact with it, and it gets into your body really easily. You are right that the "BPA-free" products hysteria is a gimmick, because what companies have replaced BPA with are BPA analogs that are actually worse in this regard of blocking sex hormone activity.

What's so brutal about the concept of xenoestrogens like BPA and BPA analogs is that you can get all the bloodwork done that you want, and it might show you to have super high testosterone levels, but if your body is full of xenoestrogens then all that test has nowhere to bind to and you will basically live as someone who has low to no test despite all your bloodwork saying you are perfectly healthy. THAT is the problem of BPA and pthalates and xenoestrogens, and if you care about fitness then you should be cutting that shit out of your life
